description:
Acetatifactor aquisgranensis is a species of anaerobic, Gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium that was isolated from a wastewater treatment plant located in Aachen, Germany. The cells of this species are rod-shaped and can form endospores. The optimum growth temperature for Acetatifactor aquisgranensis is around 37Â°C, and it can grow in a pH range of 6.0 to 8.0.

Phylogenetically, Acetatifactor aquisgranensis belongs to the phylum Firmicutes, class Clostridia, order Clostridiales, and family Clostridiaceae. It is characterized by its ability to ferment various carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, and xylose, and produce acetate as the main end-product of its metabolism.

The genome of Acetatifactor aquisgranensis has been sequenced, providing insights into its genetic potential and metabolic capabilities. This species has been reported to play a role in the anaerobic digestion process, where it contributes to the conversion of organic matter into methane and carbon dioxide.

Further research on Acetatifactor aquisgranensis may help understand its ecological function and potential applications in biotechnology or environmental processes, such as bioremediation or biogas production.
